translated: Abhidharma Collection of Different Aspects of the Doctrine Treatise, Scroll 11
Venerable ÅšÄriputra said
Tripiá¹­aka master Xuanzang respectfully translated by imperial decree
Venerable ones, you should know that the Buddha himself well understood and realized the five dharmas, and then proclaimed and revealed them to his disciples.

We should now gather together to compile them, so that there will be no disagreement after the Buddha's parinirvÄá¹‡a. We should cause the Dharma and Vinaya of the holy life to abide for a long time, benefiting immeasurable beings, and having compassion for the heavenly and human beings of the world, enabling them to attain supreme benefits and happiness.
What are the five dharmas?
There are two Udanas here.
The first UdanÄ says:
The first five dharmas are of ten kinds, namely the aggregates, clingings, sublime desires,
stinginess, destinies, hindrances, seeds, bonds, lower and upper fetters, each of five.

There are five aggregates, five appropriated aggregates, five sensual pleasures, five kinds of stinginess, five destinies, five hindrances, five mental thorns, five mental fetters, five lower fetters, and five higher fetters.ğŸ”½The five aggregates are:
First, the form aggregate;
Second, the feeling aggregate;
Third, the perception aggregate;
Fourth, the volitional formations aggregate;
Fifth, the consciousness aggregate.
What is the form aggregate?
Answer:
All forms, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, are all briefly gathered into one aggregate called the form aggregate.
What is the feeling aggregate?
Answer:
All feelings, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, are all briefly gathered into one aggregate called the feeling aggregate.
What is the aggregate of perception?
Answer:

All perceptions, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, are all combined into one aggregate and called the aggregate of perception.
What is the aggregate of mental formations?
Answer:

All mental formations, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, are all combined into one aggregate and called the aggregate of mental formations.
What is the aggregate of consciousness?
Answer:

All consciousness, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near, are all combined into one aggregate and called the aggregate of consciousness.
Here, what is meant by all forms?
All forms refer to the four great elements and the forms derived from the four great elements. This is called all forms.
Furthermore, all forms refer to the ten form-bases and the forms included in the form-base. This is called all forms.
What is past form?
Answer:

If form has already arisen, has already arisen equally, has already been born, has already been born equally, has already turned, has already appeared turning, has already been accumulated, has already appeared, has fallen away, has passed away, has been exhausted, has ceased, has departed, has changed, is of the nature of the past, is of the class of the past, and is included in the past time, this is called past form.
What is future form?
Answer:

If form has not yet arisen, has not yet arisen equally, has not yet been born, has not yet been born equally, has not yet turned, has not yet appeared turning, has not been accumulated, has not appeared, is of the nature of the future, is of the class of the future, and is included in the future time, this is called future form.
What is present form?
Answer:

If form has already arisen, has already arisen equally, has already been born, has already been born equally, has already turned, has already appeared turning, has gathered, has appeared, abides, has not yet passed away, has not yet been exhausted and ceased, has not yet been separated and changed, is combined, is present, is of the nature of the present, is of the class of the present, and is included in the present world, this is called present form.
As for internal and external, what is internal form?
Answer:
If form is in this continuity, has already been obtained and not lost, this is called internal form.
What is external form?
Answer:
If form is in this continuity, either not yet obtained, or having been obtained, has been lost, or is in another's continuity, or is non-sentient, this is called external form.
As for coarse and fine, how are coarse form and fine form established?
Answer:
Coarse form and fine form are established by way of observation.
How is it so?
Answer:
If one observes form that is not visible but has resistance, then form that is visible and has resistance is called coarse;

If one observes visible and resistant form, then invisible and resistant form is called subtle.ğŸ”½If one observes invisible and non-resistant form, then invisible and resistant form is called coarse;

if one observes invisible and resistant form, then invisible and non-resistant form is called subtle.ğŸ”½If one observes form belonging to the form realm, then form belonging to the desire realm is called coarse;
if one observes form belonging to the desire realm, then form belonging to the form realm is called subtle.
If one observes unconditioned form, then form belonging to the form realm is called coarse;
if one observes form belonging to the form realm, then unconditioned form is called subtle.
Thus establishing coarse form and subtle form, this is called coarse or subtle.
As for inferior or superior, how is inferior form and superior form established?
Answer:
Inferior form and superior form are established by observation.
How is this so?
Answer:
If one observes covered and neutral form, then unwholesome form is called inferior;
If one contemplates unwholesome form, then obscured-neutral form is called superior.
If one contemplates unobscured-neutral form, then obscured-neutral form is called inferior;
if one contemplates obscured-neutral form, then unobscured-neutral form is called superior.
If one contemplates contaminated wholesome form, then unobscured-neutral form is called inferior;

if one contemplates unobscured-neutral form, then contaminated wholesome form is called superior.ğŸ”½If one contemplates uncontaminated wholesome form, then contaminated wholesome form is called inferior;
if one contemplates contaminated wholesome form, then uncontaminated wholesome form is called superior.
If one contemplates form of the form realm, then form of the desire realm is called inferior;
if one contemplates form of the desire realm, then form of the form realm is called superior.ğŸ”½If one contemplates unconditioned form, then form of the form realm is called inferior;
if one contemplates form of the form realm, then unconditioned form is called superior.
Thus, inferior form and superior form are established. This is called inferior or superior.
What is far form and what is near form?
Answer:
Past and future form are far form.
What is near form?
Answer:
Present form is near form.
Furthermore, what is far form?
Answer:
If form is past and not just ceased, or if form is future and not about to arise, this is called far form.
What is near form?
Answer:
If form is past and has just ceased, or if form is future and is about to arise, this is called near form.
This is called far or near.
What does it mean to include all of this in a single aggregate?
Answer:
Estimating, contemplating, measuring, and observing, gathering into a single aggregate. Therefore, it is called including all of this in a single aggregate.
What is meant by the aggregate of form?
Answer:
In this form aggregate, form is manifested, the aggregate is manifested, the body is manifested, the mass is manifested, therefore it is called the form aggregate.
What is meant by all feelings?
Answer:
All feelings are exhausted, namely the six groups of feeling.
What are the six?
Namely, feeling born of eye contact, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact. Such are called all feelings.
If past, future, or present, what is past feeling?
Answer:

If feeling has already arisen, has already arisen equally, has already been born, has already been born equally, has already turned, has already appeared turning, has already been accumulated, has already appeared, has fallen away, has passed away, has been exhausted, has ceased, has departed, has changed, is of the nature of the past, of the class of the past, included in the past time, this is called past feeling.
What is future feeling?

Answer: If feeling has not yet arisen, has not yet arisen equally, has not yet been born, has not yet been born equally, has not yet turned, has not yet appeared, has not yet accumulated, has not yet appeared, is of the nature of the future, is of the class of the future, and is categorized as the future time, this is called future feeling.
What is present feeling?

Answer: If feeling has already arisen, has already arisen equally, has already been born, has already been born equally, has already turned, has already appeared, has accumulated and appeared, abides but has not yet ceased, has not yet been exhausted, has not yet been separated from, has not yet changed, is combined and present, is of the nature of the present, is of the class of the present, and is categorized as the present time, this is called present feeling.
As for internal and external, what is internal feeling?
Answer:
If feeling is in this continuity, has been obtained and not lost, this is called internal feeling.
What is external feeling?
Answer:ğŸ”½If feeling is in this continuity, either not yet obtained, or obtained but lost, or in another's continuity, this is called external feeling.
Here is the corrected and aligned text:
As for coarse and fine, how are coarse and fine feelings established?
Answer:
Coarse and fine feelings are established by comparison.
How so?
Answer:

If one compares the feeling of only having investigation and no analysis to the feeling of having both investigation and analysis, then the feeling of having both investigation and analysis is called coarse;ğŸ”½if one compares the feeling of having both investigation and analysis to the feeling of only having investigation and no analysis, then the feeling of only having investigation and no analysis is called fine.ğŸ”½If one compares the feeling of neither investigation nor analysis to the feeling of only having investigation and no analysis, then the feeling of only having investigation and no analysis is called coarse;

if one compares the feeling of only having investigation and no analysis to the feeling of neither investigation nor analysis, then the feeling of neither investigation nor analysis is called fine.ğŸ”½If one compares the feeling of the desire realm to the feeling of the form realm, then the feeling of the desire realm is called coarse;

if one compares the feeling of the form realm to the feeling of the desire realm, then the feeling of the form realm is called fine.ğŸ”½If one compares the feeling of the formless realm to the feeling of the form realm, then the feeling of the form realm is called coarse;ğŸ”½if one compares the feeling of the form realm to the feeling of the formless realm, then the feeling of the formless realm is called fine.
If one compares the feeling of the unconditioned to the feeling of the formless realm, then the feeling of the formless realm is called coarse;
If one contemplates the feeling of the formless realm, then the unconditioned feeling is called subtle.
Such establishment of coarse feeling and subtle feeling is called coarse or subtle.
What is meant by inferior or superior feeling?
The answer is:
Inferior and superior feelings are established by comparison.
How is this so?
The answer is:

If one compares and contemplates covered and neutral feelings, then unwholesome feelings are called inferior;ğŸ”½if one compares and contemplates unwholesome feelings, then covered and neutral feelings are called superior.
If one compares and contemplates uncovered and neutral feelings, then covered and neutral feelings are called inferior;
if one compares and contemplates covered and neutral feelings, then uncovered and neutral feelings are called superior.
If one compares and contemplates contaminated wholesome feelings, then uncovered and neutral feelings are called inferior;
if one compares and contemplates uncovered and neutral feelings, then contaminated wholesome feelings are called superior.
If one compares and contemplates uncontaminated wholesome feelings, then contaminated wholesome feelings are called inferior;
If one considers contaminated wholesome feelings, then uncontaminated wholesome feelings are called superior.
If one considers feelings of the form realm, then feelings of the desire realm are called inferior;
if one considers feelings of the desire realm, then feelings of the form realm are called superior.
If one considers feelings of the formless realm, then feelings of the form realm are called inferior;
if one considers feelings of the form realm, then feelings of the formless realm are called superior.
If one considers unconditioned feelings, then feelings of the formless realm are called inferior;
if one considers feelings of the formless realm, then unconditioned feelings are called superior.
Thus, inferior feelings and superior feelings are established. This is called inferior or superior.
As for distant or near, what are distant feelings?
Answer:
Past and future feelings.
What are near feelings?
Answer:
Present feelings.
Furthermore, what are distant feelings?
Answer:
If one experiences past [feelings] that have not ceased immediately, or if one experiences future [feelings] that are not presently arising, these are called distant feelings.
What are near feelings?
Answer:
If one experiences past [feelings] that have just ceased immediately, or if one experiences future [feelings] that are presently arising, these are called near feelings.
This is called distant or near.
What does it mean to summarize all of these into one aggregate?
Answer:
Investigating, contemplating, measuring, and observing, they are gathered into one aggregate. Therefore, it is called summarizing all of these into one aggregate.
What is meant by the aggregate of feeling? What is meant by the aggregate of feeling?
Answer:
In this aggregate of feeling, feeling is revealed, the aggregate is revealed, the body is revealed, and the collection is revealed. Therefore, it is called the aggregate of feeling.
What are all the perceptions? What are called all the perceptions?
Answer:
All the perceptions are called the six bodies of perception.
What are the six?
It refers to the thoughts produced by eye contact, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact. Such are called all thoughts.
What is past thought? What is future thought? What is present thought?
Answer:

If a thought has already arisen, has already arisen equally, has already been born, has already been born equally, has already turned, has already appeared turning, has already been accumulated, has already appeared, has fallen away, has passed away, has perished, has ceased, has changed, is of the nature of the past, is of the class of the past, and is included in the past time, this is called past thought.
What is future thought?
Answer:

If a thought has not yet arisen, has not yet arisen equally, has not yet been born, has not yet been born equally, has not yet turned, has not yet appeared turning, has not been accumulated, has not appeared, is of the nature of the future, is of the class of the future, and is included in the future time, this is called future thought.
What is present thought?
Answer:

If a thought has arisen, has arisen equally, has been born, has been born equally, has turned, has appeared turning, has accumulated, has appeared, and abides, not yet ceased, not yet exhausted, not yet departed and changed, combined, present, of the nature of the present, of the class of the present, included in the present world, this is called present thought.
As for internal and external, what is internal thought?
Answer:
If a thought is in one's own continuum, has been obtained and not lost, this is called internal thought.
What is external thought?
Answer:
If a thought is in one's own continuum, either not yet obtained or obtained and lost, or in another's continuum, this is called external thought.
As for coarse and subtle, how are coarse thought and subtle thought established?
Answer:
Coarse thought and subtle thought are established by way of observation.
How so?
Answer:
If one observes the thought with only investigation and no analysis, then the thought with investigation and analysis is called coarse;

If one contemplates the conception with investigation and analysis, then the conception without investigation but with analysis is called subtle.ğŸ”½If one contemplates the conception without investigation and without analysis, then the conception without investigation but with analysis is called coarse;
if one contemplates the conception without investigation but with analysis, then the conception without investigation and without analysis is called subtle.
If one contemplates the conception of the desire realm, then the conception of the form realm is called coarse;

if one contemplates the conception of the form realm, then the conception of the desire realm is called subtle.ğŸ”½If one contemplates the conception of the formless realm, then the conception of the form realm is called coarse;

if one contemplates the conception of the form realm, then the conception of the formless realm is called subtle.ğŸ”½If one contemplates the unconditioned conception, then the conception of the formless realm is called coarse;
if one contemplates the conception of the formless realm, then the unconditioned conception is called subtle.
Thus establishing coarse conception and subtle conception, this is called coarse or subtle.
As for inferior or superior, how are inferior conception and superior conception established?
Answer:
Inferior conception and superior conception are established by comparison.
How are they equal?
Answer:

If one contemplates the covered and neutral thoughts, then the unwholesome thoughts are called inferior;ğŸ”½if one contemplates the unwholesome thoughts, then the covered and neutral thoughts are called superior.
If one contemplates the uncovered and neutral thoughts, then the covered and neutral thoughts are called inferior;
if one contemplates the covered and neutral thoughts, then the uncovered and neutral thoughts are called superior.
If one contemplates the contaminated wholesome thoughts, then the uncovered and neutral thoughts are called inferior;

if one contemplates the uncovered and neutral thoughts, then the contaminated wholesome thoughts are called superior.ğŸ”½If one contemplates the uncontaminated wholesome thoughts, then the contaminated wholesome thoughts are called inferior;
if one contemplates the contaminated wholesome thoughts, then the uncontaminated wholesome thoughts are called superior.
If one contemplates the thoughts of the form realm, then the thoughts of the desire realm are called inferior;
if one contemplates the thoughts of the desire realm, then the thoughts of the form realm are called superior.
If one contemplates the thoughts of the formless realm, then the thoughts of the form realm are called inferior;ğŸ”½...
If one contemplates the perception of the form realm, then the perception of the formless realm is called superior.
If one contemplates the unconditioned perception, then the perception of the formless realm is called inferior;
if one contemplates the perception of the formless realm, then the unconditioned perception is called superior.
Thus establishing inferior perception and superior perception, this is called inferior or superior.
As for far or near, what is meant by far perception?
Answer:
Past and future perceptions.
What is meant by near perception?
Answer:
Present perceptions.
Furthermore, what is meant by far perception?
Answer:
If a perception is past and not just ceased, or if a perception is future and not about to arise, this is called far perception.
What is meant by near perception?
Answer:
If a perception is past and has just ceased, or if a perception is future and is about to arise, this is called near perception.
This is called far or near.
Thus all are briefly gathered into one aggregate: how are all briefly gathered into one aggregate?
Answer:
Estimating, thinking, measuring, observing, and gathering into one aggregate, therefore it is called thus all are briefly gathered into one aggregate.
Called the aggregate of perception: what is called the aggregate of perception?
Answer:
In this aggregate of perception, it manifests perception, manifests an aggregate, manifests a body, manifests a collection, therefore it is called called the aggregate of perception.
All volitional formations: what are called all volitional formations?
Answer:
All volitional formations refer to the six kinds of bodily volitional formations.
What are the six?
Namely, volitional formations born from eye contact, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact. Such are called all volitional formations.
Whether past, future, or present: what are past volitional formations?
Answer:

If the action has already arisen, has already been initiated, has already been born, has already been produced, has already been turned, has already been manifested, has already been accumulated, has already appeared, has passed away, has ended, has ceased, has departed, has changed, and is categorized as past, past in kind, and past in time, it is called past action.
What is future action?
Answer:

If the action has not yet arisen, has not yet been initiated, has not yet been born, has not yet been produced, has not yet been turned, has not yet been manifested, has not been accumulated, has not appeared, is categorized as future, future in kind, and future in time, it is called future action.
What is present action?
Answer:

If the action has already arisen, has already been initiated, has already been born, has already been produced, has already been turned, has already been manifested, has been accumulated, has appeared, abides without having already passed away, without having already ended, without having already ceased, without having already departed, without having already changed, and is categorized as present, present in kind, and present in time, it is called present action.
What is internal action? What is external action?
Answer:
If a practice exists in this continuum, has been attained and not lost, it is called an internal practice.
What is an external practice?
Answer:

If a practice exists in this continuum, either it has not been attained before, or it has been attained but lost, or it belongs to another continuum, or it is not a sentient being, it is called an external practice.
What is coarse and what is subtle? How are coarse and subtle practices established?
Answer:
They are established by comparison.
How so?

Answer:ğŸ”½If one compares a practice with only investigation and no analysis to a practice with both investigation and analysis, then the practice with both investigation and analysis is called coarse;

if one compares a practice with both investigation and analysis to a practice with only investigation and no analysis, then the practice with only investigation and no analysis is called subtle.ğŸ”½If one compares a practice with neither investigation nor analysis to a practice with only investigation and no analysis, then the practice with only investigation and no analysis is called coarse;
if one compares a practice with only investigation and no analysis to a practice with neither investigation nor analysis, then the practice with neither investigation nor analysis is called subtle.
If one compares practices of the desire realm to practices of the form realm, then practices of the desire realm are called coarse;

If one observes in relation to the practices of the desire realm, then the practices of the form realm are called subtle.ğŸ”½If one observes in relation to the practices of the formless realm, then the practices of the form realm are called coarse;

if one observes in relation to the practices of the form realm, then the practices of the formless realm are called subtle.ğŸ”½If one observes in relation to the practices of the unconditioned, then the practices of the formless realm are called coarse;
if one observes in relation to the practices of the formless realm, then the practices of the unconditioned are called subtle.
Thus establishing coarse practices and subtle practices, this is called coarse or subtle.
What is meant by establishing inferior practices and superior practices?
Answer:
Establishing inferior practices and superior practices in relation to observation.
How is this so?

Answer:ğŸ”½If one observes in relation to the practices of the obscured and indeterminate, then the unwholesome practices are called inferior;ğŸ”½if one observes in relation to the unwholesome practices, then the practices of the obscured and indeterminate are called superior.
If one observes in relation to the practices of the unobscured and indeterminate, then the practices of the obscured and indeterminate are called inferior;
If one contemplates the unwholesome and indeterminate actions, then the indeterminate actions are called superior.
If one contemplates the contaminated wholesome actions, then the indeterminate actions are called inferior;

if one contemplates the indeterminate actions, then the contaminated wholesome actions are called superior.ğŸ”½If one contemplates the uncontaminated wholesome actions, then the contaminated wholesome actions are called inferior;
if one contemplates the contaminated wholesome actions, then the uncontaminated wholesome actions are called superior.
If one contemplates the actions of the form realm, then the actions of the desire realm are called inferior;
if one contemplates the actions of the desire realm, then the actions of the form realm are called superior.
If one contemplates the actions of the formless realm, then the actions of the form realm are called inferior;
if one contemplates the actions of the form realm, then the actions of the formless realm are called superior.

If one contemplates the unattached actions, then the actions of the formless realm are called inferior;ğŸ”½if one contemplates the actions of the formless realm, then the unattached actions are called superior.
Thus, inferior and superior practices are established. This is called inferior or superior.
What is meant by distant or near? What is meant by distant practice?
Answer:
Past and future practices.
What is meant by near practice?
Answer:
Present practices.
Furthermore, what is meant by distant practice?
Answer:
If a practice is past but not just ceased, or if a practice is future but not presently arising, it is called distant practice.
What is meant by near practice?
Answer:
If a practice is past and has just ceased, or if a practice is future and is presently arising, it is called near practice.
This is called distant or near.
What is meant by all of them being briefly gathered into one group?
Answer:
Estimating, contemplating, measuring, and observing them, they are gathered into one group. Therefore, it is called all of them being briefly gathered into one group.
What is meant by being called the aggregate of mental formations?
Answer:
In this aggregate of formations, formations, aggregates, bodies, and heaps are manifested, therefore it is called the aggregate of formations.
What is meant by all consciousness?
Answer:
All consciousness means the six groups of consciousness.
What are the six?
Namely, eye consciousness, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness. This is called all consciousness.
What is past consciousness, what is future consciousness, what is present consciousness?
Answer:

If consciousness has already arisen, has already arisen equally, has already been born, has already been born equally, has already turned, has already appeared turning, has already been accumulated, has already appeared, has fallen away, has passed away, has ended, has ceased, has departed, has changed, is of the nature of the past, is of the class of the past, is included in the past time, this is called past consciousness.
What is future consciousness?
Answer:

If consciousness has not yet arisen, not yet arisen equally, not yet born, not yet born equally, not yet turned, not yet manifestly turned, not yet accumulated, not yet appeared, it is categorized as the future nature, future type, and future time. This is called future consciousness.
What is present consciousness?
Answer:

If consciousness has already arisen, already arisen equally, already born, already born equally, already turned, already manifestly turned, accumulated and appeared, abiding without yet having ceased, without yet having been exhausted and extinguished, without yet having been separated and transformed, combined and present, it is categorized as the present nature, present type, and present time. This is called present consciousness.
As for internal and external, what is internal consciousness?
Answer:
If consciousness is in this continuity, has been obtained and not lost, this is called internal consciousness.
What is external consciousness?
Answer:
If consciousness is in this continuity, either not yet obtained, or obtained and already lost, or in another's continuity, this is called external consciousness.
As for coarse and subtle, how are coarse and subtle consciousnesses established?
Answer:
Coarse and subtle consciousnesses are established in dependence.
How so?
Answer:ğŸ”½If one depends on consciousness without investigation with only deliberation, then consciousness with investigation and with deliberation is called coarse;

if one depends on consciousness with investigation and with deliberation, then consciousness without investigation with only deliberation is called subtle.ğŸ”½If one depends on consciousness without investigation and without deliberation, then consciousness without investigation with only deliberation is called coarse;

if one depends on consciousness without investigation with only deliberation, then consciousness without investigation and without deliberation is called subtle.ğŸ”½If one depends on consciousness of the form realm, then consciousness of the desire realm is called coarse;

if one depends on consciousness of the desire realm, then consciousness of the form realm is called subtle.ğŸ”½If one depends on consciousness of the formless realm, then consciousness of the form realm is called coarse;
if one depends on consciousness of the form realm, then consciousness of the formless realm is called subtle.
If one depends on unattached consciousness, then consciousness of the formless realm is called coarse;
If one contemplates the consciousness of the formless realm, then the unattached consciousness is called subtle.
Such establishment of coarse consciousness and subtle consciousness is called coarse or subtle.
What is meant by inferior or superior consciousness?
The answer is:
Inferior and superior consciousness is established by comparison.
How is this so?
The answer is:

If one compares with the covered and neutral consciousness, then the unwholesome consciousness is called inferior;ğŸ”½if one compares with the unwholesome consciousness, then the covered and neutral consciousness is called superior.
If one compares with the uncovered and neutral consciousness, then the covered and neutral consciousness is called inferior;
if one compares with the covered and neutral consciousness, then the uncovered and neutral consciousness is called superior.
If one compares with the contaminated wholesome consciousness, then the uncovered and neutral consciousness is called inferior;
if one compares with the uncovered and neutral consciousness, then the contaminated wholesome consciousness is called superior.
If one compares with the uncontaminated wholesome consciousness, then the contaminated wholesome consciousness is called inferior;
If one observes contaminated wholesome consciousness, then uncontaminated wholesome consciousness is called superior.
If one observes consciousness of the form realm, then consciousness of the desire realm is called inferior;
if one observes consciousness of the desire realm, then consciousness of the form realm is called superior.
If one observes consciousness of the formless realm, then consciousness of the form realm is called inferior;
if one observes consciousness of the form realm, then consciousness of the formless realm is called superior.
If one observes unattached consciousness, then consciousness of the formless realm is called inferior;
if one observes consciousness of the formless realm, then unattached consciousness is called superior.
Thus, inferior consciousness and superior consciousness are established. This is called inferior or superior.
As for far or near, what is far consciousness?
Answer:
Past and future consciousness.
What is near consciousness?
Answer:
Present consciousness.
Furthermore, what is far consciousness?
Answer:
If consciousness is past and not immediately ceased, or if consciousness is future and not presently arising, it is called distant consciousness.
What is near consciousness?
Answer:
If consciousness is past and has just ceased, or if consciousness is future and is presently arising, it is called near consciousness.
This is called distant or near.
What does it mean to summarize all of these as a single aggregate?
Answer:
Investigating, contemplating, measuring, and observing, they are gathered into a single aggregate. Therefore, it is called summarizing all of these as a single aggregate.
What is meant by the aggregate of consciousness? What is meant by the aggregate of consciousness?ğŸ”½Answer:
In this aggregate of consciousness, consciousness is revealed, the aggregate is revealed, the body is revealed, and the collection is revealed. Therefore, it is called the aggregate of consciousness.
The five appropriated aggregates are: first, the appropriated aggregate of form;ğŸ”½second, the appropriated aggregate of feeling;
third, the appropriated aggregate of perception;
fourth, the appropriated aggregate of volitional formations;
fifth, the appropriated aggregate of consciousness.
What is the form aggregate of clinging?
Answer:

If form is contaminated and in accordance with clinging, then with regard to this form, whether past, future, or present, when desire arises, there is either greed, or ill-will, or delusion, or any of the subsidiary defilements of the mind. This is called the form aggregate of clinging.
What is the feeling aggregate of clinging?
Answer:

If feeling is contaminated and in accordance with clinging, then with regard to this feeling, whether past, future, or present, when desire arises, there is either greed, or ill-will, or delusion, or any of the subsidiary defilements of the mind. This is called the feeling aggregate of clinging.
What is the perception aggregate of clinging?
Answer:

If perception is contaminated and in accordance with clinging, then with regard to this perception, whether past, future, or present, when desire arises, there is either greed, or ill-will, or delusion, or any of the subsidiary defilements of the mind. This is called the perception aggregate of clinging.
What is the formations aggregate of clinging?
Answer:

If one practices with outflows in accordance with various attachments, when desire arises for these formations, whether past, future, or present, one may give rise to greed, anger, or delusion, or any of the various subsidiary afflictions associated with the mind. This is called the aggregate of formations that are grasped.
What is the aggregate of consciousness that is grasped?
Answer:

If consciousness is with outflows in accordance with various attachments, when desire arises for this consciousness, whether past, future, or present, one may give rise to greed, anger, or delusion, or any of the various subsidiary afflictions associated with the mind. This is called the aggregate of consciousness that is grasped.

The five kinds of subtle desires: First, forms cognized by the eye that are lovely, delightful, pleasing, and attractive, these lovely forms can lead to various desires and attachments, called the subtle desire of forms cognized by the eye.

Second, sounds cognized by the ear that are lovely, delightful, pleasing, and attractive, these lovely sounds can lead to various desires and attachments, called the subtle desire of sounds cognized by the ear.

Fourth, the fragrant scents that are cognized by the nose, which are lovable, enjoyable, delightful, and pleasing, these lovable fragrant scents can lead to various desires and conform to defilement and attachment, are called the wonderful desires cognized by the nose.ğŸ”½Fifth, the flavors that are cognized by the tongue, which are lovable, enjoyable, delightful, and pleasing, these lovable flavors can lead to various desires and conform to defilement and attachment, are called the wonderful desires cognized by the tongue.

Sixth, the tactile objects that are cognized by the body, which are lovable, enjoyable, delightful, and pleasing, these lovable tactile objects can lead to various desires and conform to defilement and attachment, are called the wonderful desires cognized by the body.
What are the wonderful desires cognized by the eye?
Answer:
If form belongs to the desire realm, arises from eye contact, and is the object of craving, it is called the wonderful desires cognized by the eye.
What are the wonderful desires cognized by the ear?
Answer:
If sound belongs to the desire realm, arises from ear contact, and is the object of craving, it is called the wonderful desires cognized by the ear.
What are the wonderful desires cognized by the nose?
Answer:
If a smell belongs to the desire realm, arises from nose contact, and is the object of craving, it is called the subtle desire cognized by the nose.
What is the subtle desire cognized by the tongue?
Answer:
If a taste belongs to the desire realm, arises from tongue contact, and is the object of craving, it is called the subtle desire cognized by the tongue.
What is the subtle desire cognized by the body?
Answer:
If a touch belongs to the desire realm, arises from body contact, and is the object of craving, it is called the subtle desire cognized by the body.
There are five kinds of stinginess: 1. stinginess about dwelling places;
2. stinginess about families;
3. stinginess about praise of appearance;
4. stinginess about material gain;
5. stinginess about the Dharma.
What is stinginess about dwelling places?
Answer:
If one is attached to a dwelling place and fixates the mind there, thinking:
May this dwelling place belong to me and not to others.
I will walk, sit, and enjoy myself here. May no one else get it.

They are attached to their dwelling place and obstruct and prevent others from using it, not giving, not bestowing, not following in giving, not abandoning, not relinquishing, not completely abandoning. This is called stinginess about dwelling places.
What is stinginess about families?
Answer:
If one is attached to a donor's family and thinks:
This donor's family belongs to me, not to others.
I alone enter and leave this family, come and go, associate closely, dwell and enjoy myself here. Let no one else obtain it.

They are attached to the donor's family and obstruct and prevent others from using it, not giving, not bestowing, not following in giving, not abandoning, not relinquishing, not completely abandoning. This is called stinginess about families.
What is stinginess about praise of form?
Answer:
If one is attached to praise of form and thinks:
May I alone attain a subtle and wonderful appearance, a face that is pleasing to all, and perfect purity and perfection, with all the visible forms surpassing others.
May I alone attain a vast reputation, good fame, and good praise, spreading in all directions and universally praised by the world, surpassing others.

Only I know well how to enjoy food and other necessities, causing food and drink to be digested in a timely manner, and the necessities to nourish and grow, with a radiant complexion and delicate skin, loved by all, surpassing others.
Only I know well how to wear crowns, belts, clothes, and adornments, and to decorate the appearance to be extremely beautiful, surpassing all others.

He, regarding the praise of form, clings to it and fixates his mind on it, obstructing and stopping it for other sentient beings, not giving, not bestowing, not following in giving, not abandoning, not relinquishing, and not completely abandoning. This is called stinginess with the praise of form.
What is stinginess with material gain?
Answer:
If one is attached to and fixates on material gain, thinking like this:
May I alone obtain worldly material gain, and others cannot obtain it.
May I alone be selected to receive various material gains, and others are not selected.

May I alone be known to possess great blessings and wisdom, and at any time receive donations of clothing, food and drink, bedding, medicine, and other resources, and no one in the world can compare to me.

They are attached to and fixate on material gain, obstructing and stopping it for other sentient beings, not giving, not freely giving, not abandoning, not completely abandoning, this is called stinginess with material gain.
What is stinginess with the Dharma?
Answer:
If one is attached to and fixates on the teachings, thinking like this:
May I alone be able to expound the true Dharma, and others are all unable.
May I alone be able to make others recite it, and others are all unable.
May I alone be able to ask and answer, while the others are all unable.
May I alone be able to uphold the sutras, the Vinaya, and the Abhidharma, while the others are all unable.
May I alone be able to distinguish and explain the treatises composed by those who teach well, as well as compose them myself, while the others are all unable.

They are attached to the teachings and fixate their minds on them, obstructing and stopping others, not giving, not freely giving, not abandoning, not completely abandoning. This is called stinginess with the Dharma.
The five destinies are: 1. The destiny of hell;
2. The destiny of animals;
3. The destiny of hungry ghosts;
4. The destiny of humans;
5. The destiny of gods.
What is the destiny of hell?
Answer:
It is of the same nature and class as the hells, with the same life-destiny, attainment of existence, and attainment of location.
If there is any unobscured indeterminate form, feeling, perception, mental formations, or consciousness that has already been born in hell, this is called the hell realm.

Furthermore, due to the practice, cultivation, and frequent performance of the most serious bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct, one goes to hell, is born in hell, and forms the connection to be born in hell. This is called the hell realm.
Furthermore, the hell realm is called by various names, phrases, expressions, and designations. Therefore, it is called the hell realm.
What is the animal realm?
Answer:
Having the same nature and class as animals, with the same continuity, attainment of objects, and attainment of places.
If there is any unobscured indeterminate form, feeling, perception, mental formations, or consciousness that has already been born as an animal, this is called the animal realm.

Furthermore, due to the dull and stupid bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct, one goes to the animal realm, is born in the animal realm, and forms the connection to be born in the animal realm.
This is called the animal realm.
Furthermore, the animal realm is called, named, verbally designated, conceptually discriminated, and conventionally expressed as such, therefore it is called the animal realm.
What is the ghost realm?
Answer:
It is of the same nature and class as the various ghosts, with the same life-destiny, obtaining support, obtaining things, and obtaining places.
Whatever form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness there is that arises having been born in the ghost realm, being indeterminate and unobscured, this is called the ghost realm.

Furthermore, by the bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct of stinginess, whether practiced, cultivated, or done much, one goes to the ghost realm, is born in the ghost realm, and forms the birth of the ghost realm. This is called the ghost realm.
Furthermore, the ghost realm is called, named, verbally designated, conceptually discriminated, and conventionally expressed as such, therefore it is called the ghost realm.
What is the human realm?
Answer:
It is of the same nature and class as the various humans, with the same life-destiny, obtaining support, obtaining things, and obtaining places.
If there are any unobscured and indeterminate forms, feelings, perceptions, volitional formations, and consciousnesses that have already been born among humans, this is called the human realm.

Moreover, due to inferior bodily good conduct, verbal good conduct, and mental good conduct, if one practices, cultivates, and does much, one goes to the human realm, is born in the human realm, and connects with birth in the human realm. This is called the human realm.
Moreover, the human realm is a name, a designation, an additional term, a conception, and a conventional expression. Therefore, it is called the human realm.
What is the heavenly realm?
Answer:
It is of the same nature and class as the heavenly beings, with the same continuity, and obtains the basis, obtains the attainment, and obtains the place.
If there are any unobscured and indeterminate forms, feelings, perceptions, volitional formations, and consciousnesses that have already been born among the gods, this is called the heavenly realm.

Furthermore, by means of superior bodily good conduct, verbal good conduct, and mental good conduct, if one practices, cultivates, and does much, one goes to the heavens, is born in the heavens, and forms heavenly rebirths. This is called the heavenly realm.

Furthermore, the heavenly realm is a name, a designation, an additional term, a conception, a conventional expression, and therefore it is called the heavenly realm.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
